questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is/are false.
question_texts: Which of the following statements is/are false.

options.option_text: SMTP is a mail delivery protocol.
SMTP is a protocol to retrieve email from an email server.
IMAP is a mail delivery protocol.
IMAP is a protocol to retrieve email from an email server.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are correct regarding CDN.
question_texts: Which of the following is/are correct regarding CDN.

options.option_text: CDN is an acronym for Content Delivery Network.
CDN is a group of servers that helps in fast delivery of web contents.
Web content is always delivered from the closest server to the client in thenetwork.

options.option_text: Replit.com is an example of a javascript engine.

options.option_text: Ajax requests on each UI change
Vue bindings to update data reactively
Pure static pages with all updates rendered from server

questions.question_text_1: You are trying to build a distributed system with N servers, each of which may need to communicate with any of the other servers. Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: You are trying to build a distributed system with N servers, each of which may need to communicate with any of the other servers. Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: With point-to-point communication, the number of connection links will growas O(n).
With point-to-point communication, the number of connection links will growas O(n2).
With the use of a central message broker, the number of connection links willgrow as O(n).
With the use of a central message broker, the number of connection links willgrow as O(n2).

options.option_text: A webhook uses web socket protocol.
A webhook receiver must be deployed on the same origin as the webhookinitiator.
A webhook is supposed to be used for machine to machine communication

question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding long and short polling?

options.option_text: A webhook is the same as short polling.
The short polling can be used to know the state of an asynchronous task, andtrigger an action if the task gets completed.
The long polling cannot be achieved using HTTP protocol.
Long Polling can be used to achieve real time communication

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding caching?

options.option_text: It is recommended to cache the social networking apps feed responses for alonger duration.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Modern Application Development II"** exam, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships. --- --- ### **Core Topics & Concepts** #### **1. Web Protocols & Communication** - **SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol)** - Used for **sending/mail delivery** (not retrieval). - Port: 25 (or 587 for TLS). - **IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol)** - Used for **retrieving emails** from a server. - Port: 143 (or 993 for SSL). - **HTTP/HTTPS** - Stateless protocol; used for webhooks, APIs, and polling. - **WebSockets** - Full-duplex, persistent connection (not used in webhooks). - **Webhooks** - **HTTP-based** (not WebSocket). - Machine-to-machine communication (e.g., GitHub webhooks). - Receiver can be on a **different origin** than the initiator. - **Point-to-Point vs. Message Broker** - **Point-to-point (P2P):** Connections grow as **O(n²)** (each server connects to every other server). - **Message Broker (e.g., Redis, RabbitMQ):** Connections grow as **O(n)** (all servers connect to a central broker). #### **2. Distributed Systems & Task Queues** - **Celery** - **Task queue** for asynchronous job execution. - Requires a **broker** (e.g., Redis, RabbitMQ). - Supports: - Task scheduling (periodic/cron jobs). - Multiple brokers (not limited to Redis). - **Not true:** "Redis must be used" or "does not support periodic tasks." - **Long Polling vs. Short Polling vs. Webhooks** - **Short Polling:** Client polls server at fixed intervals (e.g., every 5s). - **Long Polling:** Server holds the request until new data is available (simulates real-time). - **Webhooks:** Server pushes data to a client URL (no polling). #### **3. Security** - **CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)** - **Same-Origin Policy:** Blocks requests from different origins (protocol + domain + port). - **CORS Headers:** - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` (e.g., `https://abc.com`). - Preflight requests (`OPTIONS` method for non-simple requests). - **CORS Errors:** Occur if origin/domain/port differs (e.g., `https://abc.com:8080` vs. `https://abc.com`). - **CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)** - Attack forces users to execute unwanted actions (e.g., changing passwords). - Mitigation: CSRF tokens, `SameSite` cookies. - **XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)** - **Client-side injection** (malicious scripts in web pages). - Types: - **Stored XSS:** Malicious script stored on the server (e.g., in a database). - **Reflected XSS:** Script reflected in a URL (e.g., via phishing links). - **Prevention:** Input validation, sanitization, CSP (Content Security Policy). #### **4. Caching** - **Purpose:** Reduce origin server load, improve response time. - **Types:** - **Browser Cache:** Stores static assets (HTML, JS, CSS). - **Shared Cache (CDN):** Caches content for multiple users (e.g., Cloudflare). - **Redis/Memcached:** In-memory caching for dynamic data. - **Cache Invalidation:** Critical for dynamic content (e.g., social media feeds should **not** be cached long-term). - **Flask-Caching Example:** ```python @cache.cached(timeout=40) # Cache for 40 seconds def home(): sleep(30) return "hello world" ``` - **User1:** Waits 30s (cold cache). - **User2 (within 40s):** Instant response (cached). #### **5. Frontend Frameworks (Vue.js)** - **Directives:** - `v-for`: Loop through arrays/objects. ```html
``` - `v-model`: Two-way data binding (e.g., ``). - `v-bind`: One-way binding (e.g., `:class="isActive"`). - **Reactivity:** - **Computed Properties:** Cached, dependent on reactive data. - **Methods:** Re-run on every render. - **Watchers:** Trigger on specific data changes. - **Vue Router:** - Dynamic routes (e.g., `/dashboard/:user`). - `props: true` passes route params as props. - **Slots (Component Composition):** - `Default` - Filled via ``. - **Vuex (State Management):** - **State:** Single source of truth. - **Mutations:** Synchronous state updates. - **Actions:** Asynchronous operations (commit mutations). - **Getters:** Computed properties for store state. - Example (Filtering students with marks > 50): ```javascript mutations: { updateBelowAverage(state) { state.below_average = state.students.filter(s => s.marks > 50); } } ``` #### **6. JavaScript (ES6+)** - **Asynchronous JavaScript:** - **Promises:** `.then()`/`.catch()` chaining. - **Async/Await:** Syntactic sugar for promises. ```javascript async function fetchData() { try { const data = await fetch(url); return data.json(); } catch (err) { console.log("Network Error"); } } ``` - **Closures & `var` vs. `let`:** - `var` is function-scoped; `let`/`const` are block-scoped. - Classic closure pitfall: ```javascript for (var i = 0; i < 3; i++) { setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1000); // Logs 3, 3, 3 } ``` - **Classes & Inheritance:** - `extends`, `super()`, `constructor()`. - Example: ```javascript class Tshirt { constructor(size, price) { this.size = size; this.price = price; } } class LargeTshirt extends Tshirt { constructor() { super('large', 500); } } ``` - **`this` Binding:** - Arrow functions inherit `this` from the parent scope. - Regular functions have dynamic `this` (depends on how they’re called). - Example: ```javascript obj = { func: () => console.log(this) // `this` = parent scope (e.g., window) }; ``` #### **7. CDN (Content Delivery Network)** - **Purpose:** Distribute content globally via edge servers. - **How it works:** - User requests content → CDN routes to the **nearest edge server**. - **Does not guarantee** the closest server is always used (depends on CDN logic). - **Use Cases:** Static assets (images, JS, CSS), videos. #### **8. Flask (Python Backend)** - **Caching with Flask-Caching:** - Backends: Redis, Memcached, filesystem. - Example: ```python cache = Cache(app, config={'CACHE_TYPE': 'RedisCache'}) @app.route('/') @cache.cached(timeout=50) def home(): return "Cached for 50s" ``` - **Error Handling:** - `response.ok` checks for HTTP 200-299. - `response.status` returns the status code (e.g., 500). --- ### **Key Equations/Code Snippets** | **Topic** | **Equation/Code** | |-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **CORS Origin Check** | `protocol://domain:port` must match (e.g., `https://abc.com` ≠ `https://abc.com:8080`). | | **XSS Prevention** | `DOMPurify.sanitize(userInput)` or framework-specific escaping (e.g., Vue’s `{{}}`). | | **Celery Task** | `@app.task(bind=True, max_retries=3)` | | **Vuex Mutation** | `state.below_average = state.students.filter(s => s.marks > 50);` | | **Flask Caching** | `@cache.cached(timeout=40)` | | **JavaScript Closure** | `for (let i = 0; i < 3; i++) { setTimeout(() => console.log(i), 1000); }` | | **Async/Await Error** | `try { await fetch(url); } catch { console.log("Network Error"); }` | --- ### **Mermaid Knowledge Graph** ```mermaid %% Core Topics in Modern Application Development II graph TD %% Protocols A[Web Protocols] --> A1[SMTP] A --> A2[IMAP] A --> A3[HTTP/HTTPS] A --> A4[WebSockets] A --> A5[Webhooks] %% Distributed Systems B[Distributed Systems] --> B1[Celery] B --> B2[Message Brokers] B --> B3[Long/Short Polling] %% Security C[Security] --> C1[CORS] C --> C2[CSRF] C --> C3[XSS] %% Caching D[Caching] --> D1[Browser Cache] D --> D2[CDN] D --> D3[Redis/Memcached] D --> D4[Flask-Caching] %% Frontend E[Frontend] --> E1[Vue.js] E --> E2[Vuex] E --> E3[Vue Router] E --> E4[Slots] %% JavaScript F[JavaScript] --> F1[Promises] F --> F2[Async/Await] F --> F3[Closures] F --> F4[Classes] %% Relationships A5 --> C1[CORS for Webhooks] B1 --> B2[Celery needs a Broker] C3 --> E1[XSS in Vue Templates] D --> E[Caching in SPAs] F --> E[JS in Vue] ``` ```mermaid %% Focus: Vue.js Ecosystem graph TD Vue[Vue.js] --> Directives[v-for, v-model, v-bind] Vue --> Reactivity[Computed, Methods, Watchers] Vue --> Components[Slots, Props, Events] Vue --> Vuex[State Management] Vuex --> Mutations[Synchronous Updates] Vuex --> Actions[Async Operations] Vuex --> Getters[Computed State] Vue --> Router[Dynamic Routes] Router --> Props[Route Params as Props] ``` ```mermaid %% Focus: Asynchronous JavaScript graph LR AsyncJS[Asynchronous JS] --> Promises[.then().catch()] AsyncJS --> AsyncAwait[async/await] AsyncJS --> Closures[setTimeout in Loops] AsyncJS --> ErrorHandling[try/catch] Promises --> Fetch[fetch(url).then()] AsyncAwait --> FetchAsync[await fetch(url)] ``` ```mermaid %% Focus: Security graph TD Security[Web Security] --> CORS[Cross-Origin Resource Sharing] Security --> CSRF[Cross-Site Request Forgery] Security --> XSS[Cross-Site Scripting] CORS --> Headers[Access-Control-Allow-Origin] CSRF --> Tokens[CSRF Tokens] XSS --> Prevention[Input Sanitization] XSS --> Types[Stored, Reflected, DOM-based] ``` --- ### **Exam Tips** 1. **JavaScript Closures/Async:** - `var` in loops causes closure issues (use `let`). - `await` pauses execution; errors propagate to the nearest `catch`. 2. **Vue.js:** - `v-for` supports `(value, key, index)` syntax for objects. - Computed properties are **cached**; methods re-run on re-render. 3. **CORS:** - Different **ports** (e.g., `:8080` vs. no port) trigger CORS. - Subdomains (e.g., `xyz.abc.com`) are **different origins**. 4. **Celery:** - Requires a **broker** (Redis/RabbitMQ). - Supports **periodic tasks** (e.g., `@app.task(run_every=60)`). 5. **Caching:** - **Dynamic content** (e.g., social feeds) should **not** be cached long-term. - Flask-Caching with Redis: First request is slow; subsequent requests are fast (until `timeout`).
